Yes . . .
And so then . . . When we . . . In two days we arrived in Lodz.
The train must have gone fast?
No . . . It was comparatively slow. One cant' say [that it went fast] .
Were you fed on the way?

We got something from the Jewish community . . . We were fed, that is, we were given [word not clear] provisions. Possibly . . . I don't know whether the Jewish community was informed that we . . . that we were going to Lodz. At any rate, we were given sufficient food . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and when we arrived in Lodz we were assembled in a school . . . That is in Lodz . . . in a school . . . It was in a frightful condition . . .
[Few words not clear]
We, of course, were unable to imagine what that meant to live in a Lodz Ghetto.
Oh . . . You were taken to the Ghetto?
. . . to the Ghetto—Yes, to the Ghetto.
Now . . .
. . . to the Lodz Ghetto . . . There we had [to live] under the most frightful conditions, one would say from a hygienic standpoint—under conditions worse than in a concentration camp.
Now then. Continue please.
Wait a moment. [Apparently adjustment of recorder] Now then . . .

From this . . . form this single transport, which went to the Lodz Ghetto, as far as it is known at the most three [persons] have survived. Most of them either starved to death in the Ghetto—part had died of typhus, or were immediately 'resettled.' What does that mean 'resettled?' The people who were idle, who did not . . . did not accept [find] a job. Most lived under the belief that the war would soon be over. Why then should they accept a job, and that was their misfortune. I don't know what moved me to accept a job; that is . . . I was . . .
Did one have a choice, to accept?
One could . . . Yes . . . Everyone could get a job in his own trade because the Lodz Ghetto, as the Germans . . . as the Germans themselves claimed, [was] a model Ghetto.
Oh!
Under the leadership of the Jewish elder, Chaim Rumkowski.
Rumkowski?
Yes . . . who was, I would almost say, an exploiter . . .
Yes . . .
. . . in favor of the Germans. If the Germans . . . [demanded] a hundred percent, he would deliver a hundred and fifty percent. And so he . . .
What do you mean, a hundred percent?
A hundred percent production—labor production.
Yes . . .
He . . . Of course, what I [?] got [?] for it . . .
Have you any idea of what has become of Rumkowski? Where is he now?
Rumkowski was 'burned' with his whole family as soon as they arrived in Auschwitz.
Rumkowski was 'burned?'
Yes . . . Yes.
So much was reported about Rumkowski in Lodz . . .
Rumkowski was actually like a king; he behaved . . . if according to his theory . . . according to his point of view every person belonged . . . belonged to him . . .
Yes . . .
. . . Everything that one possessed, that one had, belonged to him.
Now who has elevated him to this height?
The Germans.
The Germans.
At any rate, they were very satisfied with him; that as a reward [with a chuckle] he had to go to the crematory, is a separate issue . . .
That was the German gratitude . . .
That was the German gratitude.

But wait, since you have come to the topic of Rumkowski I have already heard from others [about it] Have you heard anything about the speech he delivered when he requested the mothers to surrender their children?

Yes . . . He . . . he . . . of course, when the Germans demanded a thousand or two thousand people for work from him, so he, of course, could not explain it to them in the manner in which the Germans informed him about it. Because in such case nobody would have presented himself voluntarily. He was compelled of course . . . He attempted in a round about way . . .
. . . to convince?
. . . to convince the people—that they would present themselves voluntarily for work; under the pretext that they would go to Germany to work and would be fed much better . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and there were, of course, many, since most people suffered greatly from starvation. So he knew how to persuade them to present themselves voluntarily.
Yes . . .
And this 'voluntary' presentation was . . . meant practically death.
Yes . . .
. . . death.
Now . . .

We . . . I presented myself as a fireman—for the fire brigade . . . And I based that on the contention . . . [He searches for words; apparently not on account of a general language difficulty, but either due to emotional stress or the 'high scientific plane' on which he attempts to base his explanation]
Yes . . . That . . . ?
. . . that the body, in . . . Let us say . . . in the process of great work output . . . Well . . . [a pause] or much . . . Let's say better . . . with the scarce nourishment which we got.
Yes . . .
. . . They really did not want [they could not] to do much.
. . . wanted to do . . .
. . . They did not want to do . . .
They had to save strength . . . ?
Yes . . . You should not forget that we had to work twelve hours in the factory on a water soup and two hundred and fifty grams of bread.
What kind of factory was that?
. . . There were, of course, all kinds of factories. Every . . . I mean . . . [Word not clear] factories . . . There were all kinds . . . all kinds.
. . . of work opportunities?
. . . work opportunities. Indeed, everyone, according to his abilities . . . He worked, let us say, in a shoe factory, or . . .
And where did the shoes go to?
The shoes were, of course, delivered to the Germans . . .
Ah . . .
. . . according to orders.
Yes . . .
There were orders [for merchandise] given . . .
Aha . . .
. . . for fixed dates [of delivery] ; and delivery was made accordingly.
Was there any pay for the work?
What do you mean? For it they delivered provisions.
Yes . . .
They delivered the merchandise—the raw materials in the Ghetto.
Yes . . .
. . . and for the work they [delivered] . . .
. . . provisions?
. . . delivered provisions.
Yes . . . But if one did not work he also got his food?

Well . . . At the beginning . . . at the beginning it was not so bad. Later on the people who . . . who did [singular] not work . . . who did [plural] not work . . . were . . . they withdrew [from them] a certain ration . . .
Yes . . .
. . . That is when the period of deportations had begun.
Yes . . .
I joined, as I said, the fire brigade; and in consequence I had only outdoor service. That is, I only had to watch that there were no fires.
Yes . . .

My colleagues who arrived together with me, all of them, more or less, as said before, died of starvation or were deported. Because the people who could not work were a useless [word not clear] element . . .
Yes . . .
And they were shortly, after a brief stay . . . sent immediately to Auschwitz, or some other concentration camp. [Pause] Later, that was about in 1944.
Were you in Lodz that long?
Yes, I was . . . I was in Lodz that long . . . In 1944, about in July . . . in July, '44, it reached also the fire brigade. We were, of course, the last . . . And so . . .
What does that mean, you were the last?
Everybody . . . everybody was deported according to orders . . . That is, the Ghetto was to be cleaned out; and you were told, the then chief official Dieburg . . .
Yes . . .
. . . would tell you that we were going to Germany, to work, and that there were opportunities to be better fed, and . . .
. . . and the lager supervisor . . . What was his name?
Rumkowski?
What?
Not Rumkowski, you mean . . . ?
Yes, . . . was Rumkowski already away?
Rumkowski was there still up to the last moment.
Yes. Well . . .
You see, Rumkowski departed one transport before us.
Yes . . .
I had really a chance to remain in the Ghetto, because the director in chief, Dieburg, has said that a number of single young men will remain to clean up the Ghetto.
Yes . . .

I don't know what made me [to decide] to abandon the Ghetto . . . I don't know . . . Possibly I was convinced by the speech of Dieburg, which he directed especially to the fire brigade. I could have as well remained in the Ghetto.with my friend with whom I lived together, and who was a fireman; but I decided there and then to join the transport which presumably was to go to Germany to work. We were loaded into cattle cars—into lead sealed cattle cars; that is, eighty [persons] in each. On the average eighty per car [?] . . .
Men and women together?

Men, women, and children . . . I must say that at that moment I almost regretted that I had taken that decision. Because even if I did not know exactly that I was going to a concentration camp, I still had a peculiar presentiment that if we were traveling to work under the [favorable] conditions which were presented to us, then it appeared to me strange that we were sealed in cattle cars, without the possibility to even step out [to the toilet]
Yes . . .
And no light . . . Fortunately one of us had a drill on him . . .
Yes . . .
. . . that he drilled a small hole in the floor . . .
. . . in the floor?
. . . in the floor, so that we could throw [?] 'it' out. And so we were two days en route without . . . without the slightest possibility to move. You cannot imagine in what conditions we . . .
. . . arrived . . . ?
. . . arrived in Auschwitz.
Now wait a moment. I want to have more details, more particulars about this trip. Now then, how many people do you estimate were with you in the RR-car?
We were eighty people?
How do you know the number?

Well, we knew that about eighty [per] car were . . . We saw that they were driven in by the SS or by . . . by the SS with clubs; and to the extent to which a RR-car could at all hold a person—that many were crowded in . . . I mean, in some RR-cars there could have been a few less than eighty, some had more . . .
Yes . . .
But we can accept an average . . .
Yes . . .
. . . of eighty people.
Well . . . And there were men, women . . .
Men, women, and children, you see, with their baggage, of course . . .
They were permitted to take baggage?
Yes. They were permitted to take their baggage. This was not prohibited.
Yes . . .
As much, of course, as one could carry.
Yes . . .
Of course, the people thought that if they are going to Germany to work, so they should take working clothes . . .
Yes . . .
Everyone took his kit and caboodle—all his possessions he took with him.
And then you were sealed in the RR-cars? Were there any windows?
There were no windows. There were some small cracks here and there . . .
Yes . . .
. . . in the . . . in the RR-cars . . .
Now . . . How . . . how did you take care of your needs . . . ?
Indeed! I told you already . . . Fortunately, that person has broken a hole in the floor, otherwise we could not have taken care of our extreme needs . . .
How big was that hole?
That hole was . . . It had a diameter of about ten centimeters.
One could throw out also the feces?
Possibly [a few words not clear]
And what did the women do?
Of course, you can imagine that with the excitement [nervousness] that prevailed that everyone had the need to relieve [?] himself . . .
Yes . . . and . . .
That of course, led to utmost indecency [??] We arrived . . . under the most frightful conditions . . . we arrived in Auschwitz . . .
Could you describe the conduct of individual passengers, certain passengers for me? Let us say, were there . . .
At the beginning . . . at the beginning we were, so to speak, not in such a bad mood. We expected [?] that possibly . . .
Were you sitting or standing?
We were partly sitting, partly standing. It was so crowded that we simply could not move, you see?
Yes . . .
We were unable . . . to move in any direction.
Yes . . .
The mood was at the beginning, as said before . . . We endeavored . . . the mood . . . Well . . . How should I say it . . . ?
. . . to keep up your courage?
Yes, possibly to keep up the courage. Well . . .
Yes . . . Did you talk . . . ?
Afterwards . . . Yes, we were conversing; in part we were in good spirits—some even attempted to tell some jokes . . . in order just to disguise the situation.
. . . to overcome?
Only as the trip began to appear endless, certain individuals began to become suspicious . . .
Did you get any provisions in the RR-car?
Only that what we have taken with us.
. . . what you had with you. Did they provide water?
No. No. Just until we were sealed up, water was provided.
What did you have?
Only something . . . [He becomes very erratic] whatever was passed around . . . People attempted . . . and whoever stretched out a beaker or something of the kind . . .
They would fill it up?
He would get . . . to be sure, not always . . . not always did the SS agree to it.
Yes . . . Were the SS in Lodz?
Yes.
. . . or were these Poles or Ukrainians?
I cannot say for sure. They were . . . most of them were Germans . . .
Yes . . .
Or . . . or, what were they called—Folk-Germans?
Yes, Folk-Germans . . .
Yes, Folk-Germans . . . Also the arrival in Auschwitz was also somewhat remarkable. At any rate, when the RR-car was opened we saw the prisoners for the first time.
Yes . . .
Prisoners, in striped suits. One of them turned to me and asked me to give him my wristwatch, with the remark that anyway, I was now going to Petrus [Saint Peter]
What does that mean . . . to Pet. [rus] ?
To Petrus, that meant to the Merciful God.
Yes . . .
I could not . . .
Was that a Jewish prisoner?
I could not judge exactly . . . At such a moment . . .
Yes . . .
. . . being nervous, one is unable . . .
Yes . . .
What that was to mean I found out later.
Was it not known in Lodz what was going on in these lagers?
We are . . . We were actually cut off from the outside world.
Yes . . .
That is why we knew much too little . . . We were not . . .
Well . . . He asked you for your watch . . . What did you say?
Well, to that—nothing. I would not dream of giving him the watch. [Only in a dream could it occur to me to give him the watch] You see?
Is this the same watch?
No, that is not the same. This one I got already here.
Well . . .
When we . . . Afterwards . . . Yes, we were to get out of the RR-cars; and to leave all the baggage there.
Yes . . .

And in addition, we had to get in formation five in a row; and one in uniform . . . a uniformed [person] who revealed himself later as the physician of the lager, indicated by gestures right and left, where each one had to go. That the going to the left, looking from where I stood, meant to go into the lager, while those people who were to stand to the right were going immediately into over . . . into the crematories—that we could not . . . that, thanks to God, we did not know.
But did you . . .
At any rate, a Jew noticed . . .
Yes . . .
Now a Jew noticed how a prisoner who at . . . a so-called 'Canadian'—they were called Canadians— . . .
Yes . . .
. . . one who worked at the railroad. I don't know why . . .
. . . Why were they called Canadians?

Yes . . . They were called 'Canadians.' There is no explnation for this name. At any rate, I [?] noticed how a . . . how a prisoner who worked at the railroad, was tearing away the child . . . the child from a young woman . . . from a young woman in order to force it on an older woman.
Yes . . .
This had the following meaning: an old person, an older person was . . . was to go under any circumstances, to the crematory . . .
Yes . . .
. . . while the young, a young person, alone, not accompanied by children had a chance . . .
Aha . . .
. . . to go into the lager.
. . . And so he has taken the child away from her.
Of course. Of course, he could do that only at a moment when, by chance, the lager physician would not notice it.
Did she know that . . . ?
She, of course, did not surmise what that could signify. He took her child from her arms and transferred it [attached, forced it upon] to an older woman . . .
Yes . . .
Since she later, anyway . . .
Anyhow . . .
. . . was to be burned . . . would be burned anyhow.
Nu . . .
That was explained to us much [?] later.
Yes . . .
The march into the lager was neither, a specially cheerful one; that is . . .
. . . Tell us the details. We have to have the particulars. Well . . . ?
We marched into the lager; that is, the whole fire brigade, except the ones who departed before us.
Which fire brigade . . .
The Lodz Fire Brigade. I, of course, belonged to the Lodz Fire Brigade . . .
Yes . . .
The Jewish Lodz Fire Brigade.
Yes . . .
When I heard from the . . . about the transports in which the Jewish Police, too, were present—You see, we also had a Jewish Police . . .
Yes . . .
. . . that a large part of them were burned . . .
Why?
They allegedly did not behave decently towards the population . . .
. . . towards the Jewish population?
. . . the Jewish population.
Well . . .

. . . Of course. And since the police had a very bad name among the population, and [since] many prisoners were already in the concentration camp who previously too, were in the Lodz Ghetto; that is, those who arrived before us. So they came to an understanding with the supervisors about this . . .
. . . police?
. . . this fact, and for them [prisoners—supervisors of the crematories] it, of course, made no difference who they were burning—true?
Yes . . .
And so . . .
What kind of supervisors? Were the supervisors Jewish prisoners?
There were not only . . . No, there was among them, let us say . . . as a consequence of their own situation [?] . . .
. . . a certain solidarity with other prisoners?
. . . There were some who occupied a privileged position—such as capo . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and the like.
Let me see whether I understand you correctly. The prisoners who had something against the Jewish policemen—the Jewish . . .
Yes . . .
. . . prisoners, . . .
Yes . . .
. . . had them . . .
. . . later, as these [policemen] arrived . . .
. . . later, as these arrived . . . made arrangements . . .
. . . took notice of them [??] or made such arrangements [arranged it] that these were immediately shoved into the oven.
. . . were shoved . . . Well . . .

We were then assembled in a square, and we were ordered to throw on the ground anything that we had in our pockets; that means watches, gold, etc.,—that is, everything that we still had because we had to abandon the baggage anyway . . .
Now, who . . .
Say, somebody had a watch—a wristwatch, a ring . . .
Yes . . .
. . . or anything else that presented any kind of value; so he was compelled to put in on the ground . . .
Even a wedding band [ring] ?
Just the same. Any object. He could not keep anything.
Hm . . .
We were . . . After this took place we had to undress, the clothes . . .
. . . on the street . . . ?
. . . on a . . . No, that was in an open square, in an open square; that is, it was closely fenced in . . .
Yes. But outdoors, under the clear sky?
Yes . . . [under] the clear sky, the . . .
Yes . . .
. . . clear sky . . . Then we were . . .
What month was it?
That was in the month of July.
Yes . . . Well . . .
Then we were taken into a hall. Various prisoners sat there with razor blades, who shaved our whole bodies—shaved us completely . . .
Jewish prisoners? [?]
In part Jewish—part non-Jewish [??]
Did they use soap?
No. And [painful?] shaving—with dry razor blades, dry, dry . . .
Razor knifes?
Razor apparatus . . . No . . .
Oh, electrical?
No, No, No, No . . . Plain shaving apparatus.
The so-called safety razors?
Yes, Yes. And, of course, dry—without soap . . .
Yes . . .
And the people were expressedly shaven on the whole body . . .
Yes . . .
. . . Wherever there was a single [little] hair at all on the body . . .
Yes . . .
You can imagine how painful that is, when one is being shaved a tempo [in a hurry] and then being smattered with various tinctures [chuckle]
Why?
I don't know. Possibly for disinfection.
. . . disinfection.
. . . smarting, then one had to run through under a shower. At any rate, all kind of experiments [antics]
How?

I mean the whole procedure . . . I mean, was so awkward. The worst part was only the shaving, which was so unpleasant. Then they threw us some prisoners' clothing, size estimated on sight. The shoes . . .
Were you tattooed?
No. That . . . That I shall explain to you later.
Yes. Now . . .
We . . .
The shoes . . .
The shoes . . . the shoes we could keep on bare feet [?] That means, later one got rid [was deprived?] of them, too . . .
Yes . . .
. . . in a peculiar manner. We . . . After we camped the whole night outdoors in this manner—it was rather cold that time . . .
Yes . . .
. . . We were led into the lager proper. We were then assigned to various blocks . . . to various blocks . . .
Yes . . .
They were kind of like horse stables—just like such a horse stable . . .
Were these old buildings?
These were such barracks, barracks . . .
Specially build barracks?
No. We were taken into the Gypsy lager.
Yes . . .
We were led into the Gypsy lager; that is, before us it was occupied by the Gypsies who were all burned [Footnote 1: See story of Anna Kovitzka-Kaletzka] .
Do you know anything more about the Gypsies?
No. I cannot . . .
What was told about them?

At any rate, I know only that the Gypsies were completely—the major part of them were burned. We were led into that so-called Gypsy lager. And so we were assigned to the various blocks, crowed up to a thousand people in a hall where normally about thee hundred people possibly could find room.
Have you an idea by whom and when these blocks were built? You are talking about Auschwitz now?
Yes. I am talking about Birkenau.
Birkenau and Auschwitz are one and the same? [Footnote 2: They were different camps but closely located and under the same management.] where were the crematories? In Birkenau or Auschwitz?
[Hesitantly] I cannot [tell you that] either. I have really never thought about it. One actually had no chance to think.
Yes . . .
We were really like a herd of wethers [rams]
Yes. But you have seen the crematories—you have seen the chimneys . . .
One saw them smoking. Personally [from nearby] I have not seen them. One has to . . .
Have you seen them smoke?
Smoke—of course! And particularly . . .
How did that smoke look?
Well . . . dark smoke.
yes . . .
Dark. The . . . As already said, these blocks . . . they were thoroughly damp [?? The word he uses 'hineingefercht' or 'hineingeferzt' seems to have a colloquial meaning]
Who built these blocks? When were they built? When were they built?
This I cannot . . . tell you either.
Were they built before or were they built especially?
I cannot tell you that either, for sure.
Well . . .
Neither do I know that. At any rate, the block elder who gave the instructions—that was a Pole, not a Jew.
What did he say?
He said that he knows . . .
He was a prisoner?

A prisoner, yes. He knows especially about the Jews of Lodz, that they had gold and diamonds in their possession, and that they, in order to hide them, were capable under certain circumstances to swallow them . . .
Yes . . .
They should surrender them voluntarily; otherwise they would do all kinds of things to us and we would feel sorry later.
He said that right out openly?
Openly before us. Yes, in our block.
Was there no Gestapo man present.
No, no. He told it to us in the block.
Yes . . .

Subsequently, afterwards, in order to give us an idea, so to speak, of what it means to be in a lager, he picked out one and beat him up in such a violent manner that he fell nearly unconscious [the German stereotype, 'that he lost hearing and sight']
A newcomer?
One of us.
Yes . . .
. . . of us.
And he, himself, was a capo [a trustee]
He was . . . he was a block elder.
Yes. But he was a prisoner.
A prisoner . . . He was . . .
What . . . What did he beat him up with?
With a bar . . . , a thick club . . .
With a stick?
With a stick. Frightfully . . .
And where did he hit him?

Over the face, on the back, and all over . . . So that he could not move anymore. That made, of course, a terrible impression on us . . . And afterwards he said that everyone should lay down whatever he possesses—what he still possesses . . .
Now, you said he beat up the man, and then he said . . .
He beat him up frightfully and . . . he . . .
For what reason?
For no reason whatsoever, only to make a certain impression on us, that if anyone of us . . . of us . . . still had something in his possession, that he now . . .
. . . give it up?
. . . give it up. That means—in order that it proceed unobserved [safely??] we were driven to the other side and the people could then leave in that place whatever they possessed.
Yes . . . That was already inside?
. . . already in the block . . . in the block.
Yes . . .
After he had 'established' that what the people had left, there was too little . . .

He gave us . . . He delivered a speech to us again, and said that we would be led out in the square right away and that there shall occur a much stronger recheck. Thus, an exhortation again . . . that in case we got something . . .
. . . to surrender . . .
. . . to surrender it.
Now how could people surrender it if they had swallowed it?
That is [was?] of course, a ridiculous remark. He simply wanted to instill fear in us.
Were there people who had swallowed some gold?

No. That is, of course, a ridiculous notion of that man. He wanted to bluff us into it [Footnote 3: Other interviewees definitely claim that such was the case, and that prisoners were threatened with X-ray examinations. See story of Kaldore.] .
Well, I heard differently.
Did you hear something about it?
Yes.
Well . . . I knew nothing about it. At any rate . . .
Nu . . .
. . . were then called to the appell square, and I . . . I had then still comparatively decent shoes . . .
Yes . . .
. . . on me . . . And I observed how somebody was sort of circling around me, eyeing my shoes.
Who was that, a prisoner?
Also a prisoner.
Yes . . .
Well . . . He ordered me to take off my shoes so he could try them on. They did not fit him well, but he liked them all too much to part with them. And he threw me a pair of old tatters in return.
Yes . . .
At any rate, I was told not to do anything about it, since there is a frightful punishment for it, I [?] would be punished.
Who?
[He dismisses the subject with a mumble] Sleeping was the worst . . . in such a block.
Yes . . .
The conditions of nourishment . . .
Now will you please tell me . . . Please describe how did you sleep in such a block?
I have told you already that in such a block three hundred people could lay down normally.
Where? On the floor?
On the floor. Naturally, on the floor. Since it was made of lime [stone] squares, the floor was covered with boards. Every night these boards were laid out; in the morning they were collected.
Yes . . .
And every evening they were laid out again.
The floor was of stone?

The floor was of stone. Now the floor would be laid out with boards, and one stretched out; that is, one could not stretch out—that was impossible; and it was perfunctorily measured out [estimated] how many people . . . let us say . . .
Were there no plankbeds, no beds . . . ?
No . . . Such things did not exist. Such things did not exist by us.
Not a . . .
. . . There was only the floor.
Yes . . .
. . . and specifically, we had [to take on] a hop position.
What is a hop position?
A hop position means one sits down on the floor and the legs have to be . . .
. . . pulled in?
. . . pulled in to the chest . . . to the chest pulled in.
Yes . . .
So that about five people were sitting on each side.
Not back to back?
It meant, one with the back against the wall.
Yes . . .
And the other five ahead of him.
Yes. Well . . .
And so you can imagine in this . . .
And so people slept?
. . . in this hop position one had to spend the whole night. That meant until four o'clock in the morning . . .
Yes. From what time in the evening?
From . . . We entered the block in the evening at seven o'clock.
Yes . . .
Then the ration was haded out. The ration depended on the kindness of the particular block elder.
Well then . . . What was the ration at its best?
The ration consisted of a piece of bread, a spoonful . . . a spoonful of meat; that is, canned meat . . .
[Not clear]
. . . and a bit . . .
[Not clear]
Yes. We marched, how does one say that?—in line, into the block; and in passing by they gave us, one with a spoon . . .
[Not clear]
The piece of bread, a spoon of meat; eventually a spoon of honey that would be dispensed as a supplement to the ration. Since the block elders liked to drink liquor . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and a certain black 'trading' existed in the lager . . .
. . . between whom?
. . . between prisoners who worked outside of the lager . . .
Yes . . .
There were also prisoners who outside the lager . . . who worked outside the lager. who consequently had some contact with the peasants . . .
Tes . . .
They then brought liquor into the lager, . . .
Yes . . .
probably . . . of course, in a concealed manner.
Yes . . .
And for this the block elders paid with breads.
Yes . . .
A liter of liquor corresponded approximately to eighty breads—eighty kommiss breads [army breads or rations]
[He speaks loudly without interruption, covering with his voice the voice of the interviewer] How much [rest not clear] ? Yes. A kommis bread was enough for a person . . . Say for how long?
Yes. Officially we received one kommis bread for four—eventually for five persons.
Yes . . .
[but] the block elder would distribute the rations so that ten or fifteen people [had to share one bread]
Yes. And then he would keep the rest?
And the rest he used to obtain liquor for himself.
Yes . . .
[A chance for] a complaint, of course, did not exist; because if you would dare to complain that your portion was . . .
. . . too small, he would beat you up frightfully—near the unconscious.
Well . . .

And so [chuckle] one would accept what he got. We compared our portion among ourselves at times, going around from block to block [words not clear] inquiring, 'How does your portion look?' At any rate, the sleeping, as I already have said, was frightful. At times it was possible to stretch out, but then we were lying lengthwise just like herring. One was unable to move. Now imagine those many who had bladder trouble . . .
Yes . . .
. . . who had to get out at night, had either to walk over the head or the feet of the other.
Yes . . .
And in addition . . .
Now . . . now . . . How was that . . . ? You were sitting down [see above] you were . . .
No, eventually one could also lie down. That was by mutual agreement . . .
Yes . . .
You see? But that was a lying like herring, without a chance to move at all. One could not move at all. That was, of course, unbearable. At times, one had to turn around . . .
Hm . . .

. . . or stretch, at times, his legs or pull them in. Now if one had to step out, he had to step over the leg of another, or inadvertently step on his head. There was not enough light to see well, and so some individuals would begin to yell. The block elder who slept nearby, would start a 'sport.' 'Sport' was called, for instance, standing on the knees with stretched-out arms for about a half hour, [or] to sit in a squatting position [with stretched-out arms?]
[Not clear]
In such a squatting position. That was, of course, [done by] the block elder.
How did he sleep? Did he have a bed [?]
Yes. He had a little room for himself, such a couch [He uses the English word] .
Yes.
. . . a divan . . .
Well . . .
. . . and food was to him nothing unusual, because they had contact with the kitchen most often, since they had deals among themselves . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and they had [enough of] everything. A . . . a block elder was like a king . . .
Yes . . .
. . . because . . .
[some whispers, apparently about the position of the mocrophone] Yes . . .
I was exceptionally lucky, that after a comparatively short time, I got out from Auschwitz again.
Well . . .
When they were looking for skilled workers; you see, skilled workers were . . .

Yes. Now then, you were telling how the block elder would come in, and then proceeded to 'do sport' with the people. [Her is an example that due to the necessity to manipulate the equipment, the interviewer too, could lose track of the narrative]
Yes.
Now then . . .
This 'sport making', as said before, proceeded in the following fashion. We had to take on a crouching [squatting] position. [He uses here Hockstellung]
Yes . . .
. . . with stretched-out arms. And in this squatting position we had to remain for half an hour.
Yes . . .
That was, of course, unbearable.
Yes . . .
And after . . . ten or fifteen minutes, somebody was sent to the block elder with a plea to suspend this punishment—we shall . . .
. . . be quiet.
He did not even remain present?
No. He ordered some of the prisoners to supervise, a specifically . . .
How was it to be known that the half an hour was over?
Well, at times that took place also outdoors, under supervision; in which case he too, walked up and down. Well, that could not be avoided . . .
Well . . . but I asked how would they know at night that a half an hour has passed?
[Chuckle] Well, at any rate, the time appeared to us frightfully long . . .
Yes . . . Well people did [word not clear]
. . . frightfully long . . . We were, of course, were glad when he suspended the punishment and one could get out [chuckle] of that . . .
Yes . . .
. . . terrible position. In the morning at about four 'oclock, or half past four, we were driven out of the block. We were served a cold coffee . . .
Outside?
. . . that was outdoors. It could rain, or pour out and no chance for shelter, because the hall, the stable had to be straightened up.
And what kind of utensils were used?
For the food?
Yes.
The dishes were tin plates; of course, there were never enough for all—so a part had always to wait . . .
. . . until the others . . . the others [were] through?
. . . until the others were through.
Could you wash meanwhile?

Water was fetched in buckets, and there was . . . of course, there was nothing else besides a tin plate. That is, everything was stuffed directly into the mouth in the most primitive way and manner. We had, for instance . . .
There were no knifes or forks?
No. That was, of course . . . Of course, prohibited. We attempted at the beginning to make some little wooden sticks . . .
[In whispers] Remove your arm [from the microphone]
We tried to manufacture wooden sticks, and to consume our food with these wooden sticks . . .
[Chuckle] In a Chinese manner?
[Laughter] . . . in a Chinese way, Yes.
Yes . . .
This naturally, was prohibited to us; and whenever such sticks were noticed they were taken away.
Yes . . .
Well . . . No work was done in the Gypsy lager; that is, the major part were idle . . .
Yes . . .
That also was intolerable. All day one had to ramble. Even a pin had a value, and for a cigarette one would give away his soup, which actually meant life . . .
Hm . . .

. . . and as I have told you before, I had the unusual luck that after a comparatively short time I again got out of Auschwitz. I had never believed that I would get out from this lager alive. Imagine! As far as I may judge, it was the greatest concentration camp in Europe—of fifty-six square kilometers in size. That is, as far as the eye could ever see, you see only barbed wire. So if you could succeed to overcome one barbed wire [fence] . . .
Yes . . .
. . . which is hardly possible; so you would have innumerable barbed wire [fences] to overcome. You see, that was practically out of the question.
Yes . . .
And so one day there was a search for skilled workers . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and one from the Labor Division, also a senior prisoner, examined the people on their skills . . .
Yes . . .
. . . He was especially strict, and was very nasty at the inquiry . . .
A Jewish . . . ?
No, that was not a Jewish prisoner. He . . .
What was he?
He was, I think, a kind of Pole. At any rate, he spoke German very well . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and he examined the people concerning . . . I must say, as to their general knowledge . . .
Yes . . .
. . . this [man] form the Labor Division . . .
Yes . . .
So, for instance if they looked for mechanics, then he asked certain questions. And when you were unable to answer instantly to these questions he would slap your face . . .
[Not clear]

[Laughter] . because he was not a mechanic. Of course, the people who in their nervousness could not give immediately an answer, even if they were actually skilled workers, he would box their ears, and then they had no more right to apply.
Do you have an idea why this man was a prisoner?
I don't know what he had committed. At any rate, he carried an armband . . .
Yes . . .
[Saying] Labor Division.
Yes . . .
And he was put in charge of assigning people to work outside of the lager.
Yes . . .
And so one day when that business started with . . . with the transport; that is, a lot of people were sent away from the concentration camp Auschwitz . . .
Where to?
That's what we did not know. But one could request to be registered . . .
. . . for work?

. . . for work. Only nobody knew where they were going. I caused myself to be registered at three different places [occasions] There was some anxiety . . . The work transport had some kind of a tang. We believed that meant a trip to the oven [Footnote 4: Such registration could prove at times fatal for the prisoners. There was a definite policy of the Nazis in Eastern Europe, at least at the beginning of the war, to bleed the occupied countries and the ghettos of their intellectual manpower. In a perfideous fashion calls were made for academically trained people with the alleged purpose to put in order the city archives, libraries, etc. Prisoners were zealously competing for these assignments, and the interviews gave the appearance of strict selective examinations. But the 'lucky' winners of these contests were in many cases secretly assigned for direct extermination [Kovno Ghetto] ] .
Yes.

It often happened that it was said a transport was to go away to work, and instead of work they went into the oven. We all were very suspicious. However, we registered at the various places [categories or occasions?]
Hm . . .

I myself, did not know for what reason. I . . . My friend who came with me from Hamburg, prevailed upon me to register with a group of three hundred skilled workers. That I should . . . they were looking for three hundred skilled workers . . . and for this group I also registered.
What was your trade?
I had no trade whatsoever. I just told them that I was some kind of a specialist [laughter] . . .
Yes . . .
There was an older gentleman who selected those people.
. . . from the outside, a German?
. . . from the outside, a German in civilian clothes . . .
Yes . . .
And we explained to him what we could do; and as a result of that, he assigned us to the right or to the left; that is, the people selected were to go to the right . . .
I see you wear glasses. Did you wear your glasses also in the lager?

No. I did not have them. Unfortunately I had no glasses in the lager and consequently my eyes suffered a great deal. And I have changed my glasses here already about three times. And I am afraid that I shall have to change them for a fourth time because my eyes are very, very weak.
Well . . . What are you doing here now for the Joint?
I am here in the Filing Department . . .
Well . . .

I . . . as said before, presented myself for this group. Fortunately the man from the Labor Division did not object; and since I addressed myself to the man in High German—so he had more confidence in me than in the others who were mostly Poles.
Yes, and spoke Yiddish.
And spoke Yiddish.
Yes . . .
I told him that I worked for the firm Hochstrom [?] and Associates; that was a large company for surface and underground construction . . .
Was that true?
That was true. I have never worked there [true apparently refers to the existence of such a firm] I only used it as a pretext to get out.
Aha . . .
You know if one is in such a lager, then every means is right and proper, only to get out of such an inferno.
Yes . . .
I had some 'pangs of conscience'. I thought that if I should be examined . . .
. . . and fail to pass the examination . . .
Well, these were then not pangs of conscience—you were afraid . . .
. . . Of course, I mean I was afraid. At the beginning I was not afraid, only when I was selected . . .
Yes . . .
You see, I told the man that I had worked for the firm Hochstrom [?] and Associates, and this name of Hochstrom and Associates was sufficient for the man to . . .
[to have] . . .

. . . to have certain confidence in me, and to assign me to the right with my colleague who accompanied me in all the lagers right from Hamburg. Also one of the few survivors with whom I was from the beginning [?]
And what was your colleague?
He was a tinker [tinsmith]
Yes . . .
Now for him it was much easier . . .
Yes . . .
. . . because I was not an artisan.
Hm . . .

Three hundred people were then selected from among us, and we were to leave already the next day. We were dragged around from block to block, into all kind of blocks, and in the last moment the block elder also embezzled our bread . . .
Yes . . .

That is, the complete allotment—because he knew we would depart the next day, so he was able to embezzle the bread allotment for three hundred people. My . . . A friend of mine, a dentist who is now in Lodz, had the courage to demand the rations. For that . . . for the he 'befogged' him terribly and he was . . .
You mean he beat him up terribly? [He used the term Vernebelt, which sounds like a makeshift word meaning 'befogged' or 'blacked him out.']
Yes. He thought that . . . that in the last moment since he was designated to leave [word not clear] he worked up courage and demanded the ration [s] for us all.
Yes . . .

In response, the block elder 'befogged' him terribly, and he could not say a word, so that nothing worse would happen to him. We were then . . . We got a ration of breat—about 250 grams, a little piece of sausage, and we traveled then in open RR-cars . . .
Which portion of bread did you get then—the evening [ration] the regular one . . . ?
No, no, no. We got a ration that was [to be our] travel provision.
Yes . . .
. . . and our regular ration he embezzled from us.
Well . . .
The ration, the travel ration, we consumed in a half an hour because we did not have the ration of the evening before.
Yes . . .
So we were very hungry. So we traveled for a day. The RR-cars were open, open on both sides; accompanied, escorted by two SS men.
That means the doors of the cars [were open] ?
The doors, Yes . . .
But they were cattle cars?
They were cattle cars which were open.
See Manuscript.
And so we had a chance to breathe [fresh] air; and for us it was a certain comfort that we were already on . . . that we traveled. Through that we knew that we were not going into the oven.
Hm . . .
We landed in Goerlitz . . . in Goerlitz . . .
Where is Goerlitz?
Goerlitz is in Silesia . . .
Yes . . .

. . . In the proximity of Breslau—about a hundred kilometers from Breslau. It is a peculiar feeling when one, after such a long time, sees a civilian person again. When one is in a concentration camp, I was already in '38 in a concentration camp, in Oranienburg as a consequence of the murder of von Raat in Paris.
Yes . . .
When all . . . a large part of the Jews were arrested; I mean, those that they could lay their hands on, and they were sent to Oranienburg . . .
Where is Oranienburg?
Oranienburg is near . . . from Berlin about . . .
Yes . . .
. . . A few kilometers from Berlin . . .
And when were you released from Oranienburg?
I was then released from from Oranienburg? I was about ten weeks in Oranienburg . . .
Yes . . .
Life there was not too 'rosy,' one may say. We were . . . the so to speak, 'lager ripening' [softening up for lager conditions]
Yes . . .

. . . consisted [in the procedure] that upon arrival we had to stand about ten hours lined up before the barbed wires [fences] motionless—without moving. It was then . . . I don't know anymore what time of the year it was [NOTE: in the winter of 1938-1939. DPB] At any rate, it was unbearable. Motionless. And up there . . . there . . . there were sentries in such towers [turrets] . . .
Yes . . .
. . . These were such towers . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and the sentries had to, of course, watch that . . .
. . . that you stand. And how many hours, do you say?
Well, we stood then twenty-four hours.
That was called 'lager ripening?'
'Lager ripening.'
Were you given anything to eat?
Yes. Afterwards.
That was in '38?
Yes. Then various persons were strapped to the rack; that is such a towerlike contraption.
Yes . . .
. . . You know, these . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and they got about twenty-five on the behind, . . .
Yes . . .
. . . with an ox-pizzle [Ox-penis. German: Ochenziemer]
Yes . . .
That means . . .
. . . an ox tail?

. . . an 'ox tail,' yes [Footnote 5: The German word Schwanz means in regular parlance 'a tail;' in slang it stands for 'penis.' It was common in the Russian Czarist Army for higher officers, viz the Grand Duke Nikolas, to use a dryed and specially stretched ox penis as a riding crop, with which in moments of 'noble ire' they would strike even subordinate officers. The ox penis makes apparently not only a hardhitting whip, but a stroke with it implied a component of contempt for the victim.] .
Yes . . .
That was, of course, unbearable. The skin on the buttocks [chuckle] would break. There were specially . . .
Did that happen also to you?
No, it did not happen to me . . .
But you have seen it?
Yes, we have seen it. Also for smoking at work they would . . . there were some prisoners who absolutely had to smoke.
Yes . . .
They did it, of course, on the sly; and if they were caught they then got three . . . one or two hours of pole hanging.
What is that?

That is, they were hanged on a pole by the hands tied behind; that is, the rope was pulled up so that only the tips of the toes touched the ground [Footnote 6: See the Bramson story. In 1946, this form of torture was demonstrated in Dachau to sightseers by means of a manikin apparently to demonstrate the deeds of the Nazis.] . . .
Yes.
So he hung in this position . . .
But the tips of the toes could touch the ground?
[With emphasis] . . . but only the tips of the toes.
Yes . . .
You can imagine that when they cut him loose after two hours, he would collapse like a sack. You see? Because first of all . . .
Now, how high were the hands?
The hands were pulled up as far as it would go—he floated in the air . . .
Yes . . .
That was terribly painful . . . [as I was told] by those . . . who went through it themselves.
Well . . .

That time reigned in Oranienburg, it was the worst . . . the worst cold prevailed that could ever be remembered. I worked at the canal that time and . . . we had to shovel sand under quota, into lorries.
Yes . . .
. . . into such small lorries; and I only remember that my portion of bread, which I had in the side [?] pocket . . .
Yes . . .
. . . of my prisoner's suit, was frozen into ice. So you can imagine how cold it was. The wheels . . . the wheels would not turn anymore . . .
Of the lorries?

. . . of the lorries. We were four people assigned to a lorry, regardless of whether old or young. At times the old people could barely stand up and we had to cart them in addition. And the that time lager leader, Bugdala, an SS man, the boxing champion of the SS, an infamous scoundrel . . . he spoke little, but when he slapped one's face one tumbled over twice. And so I remember that I had to carry heavy rocks together with a colleague, and it was glazed ice [on the ground] and everything had to be done with running pace. And that, of course, is impossible. So he caught us once carrying the stuff at a walking pace, so he took down the numbers and we got then three hours 'before the charged barbed wires' . . . We had to stand three hours . . .
What does that mean, 'before the charged barbed wires?' They had . . . It was . . .
One could not touch it, because otherwise . . .
Yes . . .
It was charged with ten thousand volts.
Well . . .
So one had to stand motionless, after work. You see, that meant that after work . . .
But why before the charged barbed wire?
That was such a . . . I don't know . . . the reason.
Did something to anybody, did somebody . . . against . . .
Many, many, of course sent to the barbed wire [made contact with the barbed wire] because they simply could not stand it anymore.
Oh . . . They threw themselves against it . . . ?
They threw themselves against it. They, of course, remained stuck to it.
Hm . . .

You see . . . and they were dead. I still remember, at night . . . when we were driven at night in Oranienburg by the SS, and there was such a slope. And so we could not see that it was going downhill abruptly. The first one came stumbling . . .
Yes . . .

. . . fell down . . . They . . . You can well imagine if two thousand people came in crowding so they could not get up so quickly, we trampled over them; so that we, right from the start, brought the first dead into the camp.
Yes . . .
These were the little, painful memories . . . Yes, at times . . . Well, there were unfortunately humorous instances . . .
Yes. I should like to hear something about it.

For instance, we had . . . we were at that time ten thousand people in Oranienburg, at my time. The lager elder was at that time member of the Reichstag, and we were always compelled to sing some songs. One would stand up on a platform . . .
Where? During work?
No, no. After the end of work, when we entered the lager . . .
Yes . . .

We had to . . . They made an appell—whether all were present. We once had . . . we had to stand for twelve hours because one man was absent; that is, he had hanged himself and we had to . . . we had to search for him.
Aha . . .
And we still had . . .
And where was he found . . . ?
Oh somewhere . . . In a corner, he . . .
. . . hanged himself?
If not . . . We simply had to stand until he was found, and even if we had to stand twenty-four or thirty-six hours . . . He had to be found.
And how long did you happen to stand?
At that time . . . we stood twelve hours once . . .
Hm . . .
And so it came . . .
Didn't you have to go to work?
In that case . . . That is, that depended . . .
Yes . . .
Oh . . . Yes. Only at one Christmas we were not compelled to work for one day. That is, in place of that [work] we had to 'do sports,' drill.
What was that?
Marching . . . Right, left, right, left . . . You see? In a military fashion . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and my humble self, and a few others wanted to duck out, and reported that we had sore feet. So then one of the platoon leaders said, 'Well, we shall then march slowly.'
Hm . . .

But now there came an SS man walking up and down, and said [mocking his voice] 'What is going on?' This man [platoon leader] reported in military form, 'These people can't run.'—'What, they can't run? Run, lie down; run, lie down;' and so . . .
What does that mean?
'Run, lie down,' that means, you know, [first] running and then stretching out at full length. That was then in the winter, in the snow.
Yes . . .
He made then his . . . his 'sport' with us.
That was . . .
[A few words not clear]
. . . in the lager in Oranienburg?
Well, that was then . . . I am just telling short episodes . . .
[Not clear]
Yes . . . And so I took advantage when a detail . . .
You said, you would tell some humorous . . .
Oh yes . . . [chuckle] Unfortunately I went off the subject. I was telling about the singing.
Yes.
And so they simply gave a theme, say, 'It sat a birdie in the tree,'
Hm . . .
So then I ask you, do you know the song? So you will give me the answer 'No, I don't know it.' I don't know it either.
Hm . . .
Now you had to sing a song that you didn't know.
Yes . . .
Well, so an SS man passes by and sees that I am standing there—I am not participating in the singing [chuckle]
Yes . . .

So he says, 'Why don't you sing? So he answers, 'I don't know it.'—'What, you don't know the song?'—So he slaps him over the snout and he says, 'You should at least tear open your snout.' And in the evening there was practice in the block; that is, we had to sing in the evening in the block a song which we did not know.
Yes . . .

So you see, they demanded simply impossible things. You should sing a song that you don't know. Of course . . . Just to return to the other topic—Since we did not know the terrain, . . . we were delivered and there were already . . . we already brought in the first dead. We had to line up before the charged barbed wire and an SS man passed from one to the other and inquired, 'What is your profession?' So he says . . . so one would say—'Physician.' So then, 'You have dishonored our women.' You see . . . and he would slap him, a pair right and left. To another, 'What are you?'—'A lawyer.' So then, 'You have done in [put in prison] many of ours, of our kind of people.' So he too, got his face slapped twice. I could not understand one thing. Next to this lawyer stood a state's attorney. Apparently he was so confused that he replied to his question about his profession, that he was a state's attorney. So you can imagine what an effect it had on such an [SS] man. You understand?
Hm . . .

A state's attorney at that time! And so he told him, 'You will be shot today with cat shit.' Of course, you know how one felt. I don't know what they later did with him. At any rate, they had . . . with people who were very stout they had special fun. They were ordered to make [play] stork. They were compelled to bend in order to pick up something. Of course a person with a big belly, and the clothes did not fit them well either; they had to fasten the prisoners' garb with a rope so that the pants would hold. They knew, of course, that it was strictly prohibited to leave the block at night to eliminate. Of course, at the beginning that was not known and whoever would step out of the block was, of course, immediately shot down, because the . . .
In Oranienburg?
In Oranienburg, because the kleg lights, those were the machine guns . . .
Hm . . .

They illuminated every block; and as soon as something . . . if somebody somehow began to move in the yard he was immediately shot down. It also happened that the patrol which . . . the place . . . which guarded up, simply would attract a prisoner and tell him to come over there.
Yes . . .
We were told that it was strictly prohibited to pass beyond the patrol line, since the patrol was to shoot immediately.
Aha . . .
Many prisoners, uninformed about this . . .
. . . rule . . .
. . . rule, followed unsuspectingly the 'call' and were, of course . . .
shot down . . . ?
. . . shot down. Yes, I was telling you about . . .
[A few words not clear] And so you went from Auschwitz. Where to?
. . . to Goerlitz.
All right.
I mean, from Goerlitz . . . In Goerlitz, that was a work lager. Of course, in comparison with Auschwitz, a paradise.
Yes . . .
A work lager; it was an ammunition factory. We had to work at an ammunition factory as prisoners, always escorted by the SS. And evenings we were taken to the lager, returned.
The factory was outside the lager?
. . . the factory was outside the lager.
. . . and you say that for the first time [since Auschwitz] you have seen other people.

Yes, yes. That naturally was . . . it had an effect . . . It made a completely unusual impression on us. More so, that we worked with [free] civilian people. It was, of course, prohibited to talk to them. Still now and then one exchanged with them . . .
. . . a word?

. . . a word. And since there were Frenchmen also working, and all possible nationalities. So there was a chance to get some bread now and then from them, or by the way of barter for cigarettes to acquire now and then some supplementary food. That appeared, however, less interesting than certain aspects of the life in the ghetto.
Where?
I mean . . . if we speak again about Lodz.
[Not clear]

I think, especially about the terrible hunger. The hunger was so great that we collected rotten potato peelings in order to convert them with saccharin into . . . a kind of mush. Thus a goo just fit to clog up the stomach. You see? And with it we got a little coffee grounds, with saccharin something that we called, cutlets, you see? Dry on the skillet . . .
Oh, out of the coffee grounds.
. . . of the coffee grounds. Yes . . . of the coffee grounds, and two [tablets] of saccharin. Life was insanely expensive. We were getting one bread for the week.
. . . one bread?

Yes, an entire bread. Thus, one had to distribute it in rations. You would get a bread of two kilos. Sometimes it did not weigh two full kilos. We . . . people made a special effort to get really stale bread. A fresh bread stimulated the appetite and that was dangerous.
Hm . . .
One pleaded [for a special favor] the exact opposite of [the attitude] today [chuckle] One pleaded for very stale bread so that one would not eat so much.
Yes . . .
And so, I generally distributed it for myself, so that everyday I would eat about two slices . . .
Yes . . .

And now and then I managed a loan [chuckle] so that the last three days I had no more bread [He apparently means that he loaned the bread to others] The prices corresponded . . . It was this way for a long time, that the values of objects . . . in general, had no special values, while foodstuffs . . .
. . . were expensive . . . ?

. . . had an unbelievable value. I remember, for instance, I had a new suit of clothes with me among other things—a new suit of clothes for which I paid 350 Marks in Hamburg. So you see, it was quite a piece of wealth. And I got one kilo of flour for it.
Hm . . .

You could purchase a pair . . . a pair of shoes for a hundred grams of margarine; and you see that from these prices things, objects other than food or cigarettes, were worth nothing. And they could . . . the Germans who . . . who would at times come into the ghetto with one pound of bread or margarine, would afterwards leave with a trunkful of new things. [As often in these interviews a flashback occurs without warning] Then, for the sake of saving one's life, one was ready to sacrifice all these things. I, too, was at one time . . . I was so run down from hunger that I barely could do my duties . . . I was twice . . . I remember, I was twice brought home in a state of faint . . .
As fireman [in Lodz]

As fireman, because I was actually too weak. When I looked at myself at times in the mirror I saw death before my eyes. I remember from these times, there were one hundred and sixty-five thousand Jews at the beginning, and they came down to forty thousand Jews.
Well, many were, of course, deported . . . ?
Many were deported, but a large part died from typhus. The . . .
Now tell me, did you know a Dr. Falk there in Lodz, in Lodz [a cousin of the interviewer] ?
It is possible. You see, I have no more . . .
You don't remember?

I cannot remember for sure. First of all, the housing conditions were terrible. There was . . . They have selected for the Lodz Ghetto the worst . . . the worst section of Lodz; that is, where the worst skum had lived before. Those were mostly broken down dwellings; and people [in the Ghetto] lived under the most frightful conditions. At times the people lived ten families in one flat. You can imagine what the results were under these most horrible hygienic conditions.
Could you . . .
When one, for instance, was in need of something . . . It was very hard . . . say medicines. One had to get it by way of so-called undercover trade [sneak trade]
Hm . . .
The price was, of course, prohibitive. For instance as fireman I earned three marks, three ghetto marks . . .
Per day?
Three ghetto marks per day.
Yes . . .

The cost of a bread on the black market—one thousand eight hundred marks. You can then imagine how much bread I could buy for it [three marks] The bread . . . the soup, the water soup that one got for it, corresponded to a 'dollar course.' If there were plenty of potatoes, if the Germans would send in [to the Ghetto] plenty of potatoes, then the soup would fall [in price] say from fifty marks—it would at times reach a 'quotation' of fifty marks -
Yes . . .
. . . down to a price of two fifty . . .
But you were to get some soup 'for free?'
Yes . . . The soup [a portion] we got 'for free.' But, let us say one had diarrhea or something else . . .
Yes . . .
So he would sell it.
Yes . . .
Thus, there always stood before the kitchen a kind of trader [middle-man] who would buy up . . .
Yes . . .
. . . the tickets . . . the soup tickets for a certain price; . . .
Yes . . .
In order [to resell it] to another, a hungry one, who say [had sold] something else.
Yes . . .
Say he had sold a piece of bread . . . There were people of a rather peculiar point of view. They would sell a bread for one thousand eight hundred marks—their own bread . . .
Well . . .
And bought preferably for it, soups, in order to stuff their belly full.
Yes . . .
That was, of course . . .
Yes . . .
. . . from a standpoint of health completely wrong. Thus, if they wanted to buy something equivalent to two, three hundred marks, they would sell a piece of bread. He weighed it . . .
Yes . . .
. . . as if he would weigh gold; and the bill was then settled with bread.
Will you permit me a question?
Yes.
Could you tell me anything about . . . about the sex life from the time in Lodz and afterwards in the lager?
Well [pause] that was, of course, an unhealthy situation since male and female were housed together . . . you understand; I would almost say the people were not ashamed [embarrassed] at all.
Yes . . .
They lived a complete . . .
Now let us say, when one family lived together . . .
Yes . . .
How did they go about sexual intercourse?
I would almost say, completely without embarrassment. Because the people . . . I remember we were . . .
. . . in the presence of the children?

I remember, when we came from Hamburg a certain group of us took lodging somewhere. We were eight people, among them one woman. And she did not show embarrassment at all. She undressed completely naked in order to wash. And the people became in time . . . the same as in the lager. The life in the lager has, of course, made the people so to speak, hardsensed [devoid of sensibilities—feellings. See story of Roma Tscharnobroda]
Yes . . .
Completely devoid of feelings. One did not feel anything. Let us say, when at night . . .
You mean to say, without a sex drive?

Without any sex drive. Because the hunger . . . You should not forget that when the hunger is so intense, then one, I would say, does not think about it. I believe that one who is satiated could have such thoughts rather than the one . . . one who is starving. That comes; first of all the stomach must be full. ( It may be pertinent here to sum up the answer to a question most often asked: The sex drive was suppressed by protracted starvation and a continuous state of terror. )
Yes . . .
And so . . .
So that was no problem.

With me, you understand, that was no problem. It was indeed no problem. Whatever the people . . . possibly . . . Of course, if one worked in a bread factory he could always save himself a piece of bread . . .
[Not clear]
And you know, with a piece of bread . . . that was a fortune.
Well . . .
With a piece of bread he could buy anything. I know, at the beginning when I came into the Ghetto . . .
Let us return to the sex question [?]
. . . prostitution was so intense. On the street, for instance, girls would cling to you for a piece of bread. For a slice of bread . . .
Yes . . . Jewish girls?
Jewish girls, of course. We were in the Ghetto.
So where could they go?
They would . . . would go into a yard or somewhere. Possibly the mother was working, so the daughter . . .
Yes . . .
. . . would use the opportunity . . .
Yes.
Of course, later this led to misfortune; because the girls who were not working were, of course, in time deported.
Yes.
Who was not registered . . .
. . . as a worker?

. . . One had to be registered in some kind of industry. Since he was not registered . . . As an unemployed . . . every unemployed, as well as people who had committed the slightest offense, were deported.
Now let us return [to the original question] Let us say, a block elder in the lager . . .
Yes . . .
. . . who had enough to eat.
Yes . . .
. . . Have you any idea how he satisfied his sex needs?
About that I must tell you [a chuckle] I did not make myself any headaches, since one had so many worries . . .
Yes . . .
. . . that one . . . that one thought about it less as one [could imagine]
Well . . . Yes . . .
Of course, it was known . . . Later on I learned at the [word not clear] that many block elders had such boys . . .
. . . had boys . . . ?
. . . had boys, with whom they amused themselves. I know . . . there were children from ten to twelve years old.
And what kind of children were these?
. . . They had them . . . These, too, were prisoners.
Yes . . .
. . . They were actually supposed to go to work, but they always found a pretext to retain them in the lager. A block elder could, of course, do that.
. . . He would be registered as sick, and then . . .
. . . then he would be retained?
. . . and then the block elder would retain him.
Well. Now let us return to the general situation in the Ghetto of Lodz.
The Ghetto of Lodz . . .
Or let us say it this way. Where were you liberated?
Yes. I was liberated indirectly by the Russians, because I had left earlier . . . I left the lager one day early . . . It was already . . .
Where was that?
In Goerlitz . . .
Goerlitz, where was that?
That is in Silesia. I told you already, about one hundred kilometers from Brelau . . .
Yes.
The Russians were entrenched already, for weeks, at about eleven kilometers from Goerlitz.
Yes . . .
And strangely enough they did not advance further. They remained entrenched there, I believe, for about ten weeks.
Yes . . .

And one never knew . . . I only remember that the people from the factory often approached in automobiles almost up to the line where the Russians were, in order to fetch materials. It was completely incomprehensible to me how they could do it.
That must have been a form of Sitzkrieg [sitting war]

Yes. A kind of Sitzkrieg. They just did not advance. But certain preparations were made. We were already twice in flight from the Russians; that is . . . an order was given to us . . . to the lager . . . to evacuate the lager since, of course, the Russians were someday bound to march into the lager . . . They did not want that any evidence be left against them [against the Germans]
Yes.
And so we found ourselves on the march; and unfortunately a great number of our prisoners were shot down, especially by the Ukrainian SS who hardly spoke a word of German . . .
Why?

. . . because they could not walk. 'Everything' that could not walk was shot down on the road. At times, loaded on a truck and en route graves were dug in a forest. And I remember one day I was assigned to a commando [detail] to dig; that is, to excavate, to dig graves.
How come. [?]
. . . a detail of fifty people who had to dig graves in order to . . .
. . . to bury . . .

. . . to bury the dead from the jorney. Now the following would happen. The prisoners who were unable to march—of course, they couldn't . . . They did not want to let them remain simply laying shot down on the street; and so they [the exhausted prisoners] were loaded on a truck and together with the dead; they were then shot in the nearest forest and buried with them. Thus, I remember an SS man. He was twenty-four years old [who] made the impression of an innocent . . . [chuckle]
. . . youth?
. . . youth; as if he could not count to three. And he was the champion marksman. Every day he used to shoot down about thirty-forty [people]—he himself helped to dig the grave.
Yes . . . And what for?
. . . Probably . . . that was . . . for him it was a kind of sport. Then he ordered the dead placed in them, counted up how much room he still had left.
Yes . . .

. . . And then he ordered those innocent, unsuspecting people to get off the truck, saying 'Step down' [the word is apparently in Ukrainian and is a tentative translation] They had to step forward; and he would shoot them down with the carbine—trampling [holding down] the person's head with his foot. And so one after the other had to look on how . . . You can, of course, [imagine] how . . . [the speech tapers off]
Was that a Ukrainian?
That was a Ukrainian SS.
Yes, now then . . .

He was one of the people who were subsequently sent away at the last moment, apparently out of fear that the Russians . . . that they may fall in the hands of the Russians . . . The whole Ukrainian SS attached [to this service] were sent away—were sent away. They were frightful [people]—they were the worst evil.
Well, now tell me this . . . Now where were you liberated?
Oh, yes. And so one day before, on the 7th of August . . .
Yes.

The Russians marched in, about the 8th of August—the 8th-9th. We got out of the lager. We could do already whatever we pleased. It was a change of affairs after the lager.leader had explained to us that we were practically free . . . We could remain in the block . . . in the lager.
Was the lager leader a prisoner?
No, he was an SS.
And he did not run away?

He . . . I really must say, that as an exception he had behaved, so to speak, comparatively decent; that is, I have never seen him touching a prisoner. Such was the lager elder—he was a super-gangster.
He was a prisoner?
This one was a prisoner. But he was not a Jewish prisoner.
Now what did this SS man say?
He said that we were actually free. If we desired we could go over to the Americans . . .
Yes . . .
. . . and who wanted to remain with the Russians could remain in the lager. And from . . .
But he did say that the place [?] was being abandoned?
Yes. After that [?] there was already such a confusion that everybody did what he pleased.
Aha.
There was . . . The army was in retreat and en route . . . I was still with various colleagues [of mine] so we crossed all of Czechoslovakia . . .
So you went away . . .
We got away, and in an SS truck at that.
In an SS auto?

Yes . . . No, no, no—with horse and wagon [chuckle] We took it. It was still full of provisions, and with all real SS boots and all possible [things] And so we crossed the whole of Czechoslovakia, until we arrived in Vienna . . .
[Chuckle] And nobody stopped you, nobody . . . ?

. . . Of course, en route we met the Russians. They saw that they were dealing with prisoners so they were . . . They always let us pass. We then arrived in Vienna. That is, on the way we were, of course, very well received by the population. And you can imagine what a moment it was for us to enjoy freedom after we had given up the thought that we would ever get away.
Hm . . .

As said before, we arrived in Vienna; and in Vienna we were not permitted to remain . . . [NOTE: The spool, as often happens, ends abruptly in mid-sentence. The interviewer apparently felt that it would be of little use to continue with a new spool, since the post-liberation phase was reasonably cleared up at the start of the interview; and the interviewee himself seems to have felt that there was not much to add. —D.P.B.]
